context: In Nicotiana attenuata, release of α-bergamotene, (E)-β-ocimene and linalool was induced within 24 h by caterpillar feeding and by application of MeJA, and this release was positively related to the amount of MeJA used. A similar pattern of emission has been seen in leaves of Vitis vinifera induced by MeJA. The others terpenes (E)-β-ocimene, sulcatone and cosmene, α-bergamotene, and cis-jasmone showed the same timing for their release, which start from 48 h after MeJA treatment, with no significant differences between the second and third days (Fig. 7). (E)-β-ocimene is a component of many floral scents, and it is one of the most common of the monoterpenes that are emitted from leaves in response to damage by mechanical wounding or herbivores. It is a component of an induced volatile blend that is thought to protect plants by attracting natural enemies of herbivores, as either parasitoids or predators. Moreover, (E)-β-ocimene has a role in plant–plant interactions, in resistance to pathogens, and in tolerance to high temperatures. (E)-β-ocimene was also the predominant monoterpene released from tobacco plants inoculated with various strains of P. syringae  and its emission has been seen in peanut plants infected by the white mould S. rolsfii  .

llm_generation.summary: (3e)-3,7-dimethylocta-1,3,6-triene is a type of terpenoid that can be released by plants in response to herbivore damage, similar to other terpenes like (E)-β-ocimene. These compounds, including (3e)-3,7-dimethylocta-1,3,6-triene, are often involved in plant signaling and can function as pheromones to attract natural enemies of herbivores, thereby playing a role in plant defense mechanisms. The context suggests that these volatile compounds are part of a blend that helps protect plants, indicating a significant relationship between the terpenoid and its role as a pheromone in ecological interactions.

The context provides evidence of their roles in attracting natural enemies of herbivores, highlighting their ecological importance.
